fields.Translation: (English) Good morning everybody, I'm Matteo and I speak Lombard; to be more specific, the Brescian dialect of the Lombard language, that is spoken with its dialects in all the Lombardia region, in the South of Switzerland, and in some parts of eastern Piedmont and western Trentino. Even if Lombard is recognized by UNESCO, ISO and many linguists, like almost all the other Italian regional languages it's considered an Italian dialect, and it's not official neither in Italy, nor in Switzerland. That is a big problem, especially because it's a very endangered language. Personally, I realized that Lombard language is a language and not a dialect when I lived in Valencia, where the local variety of Catalan language is spoken and there's a stronger knowledge of minority and regional languages, compared to Italy. There, in a sensibilization project about minority languages, I discovered my own language and I started to study it, and now I'm in an association called "far lombard", that aims at keeping the language alive and is proposing a common written standard, without trying to uniformate the spoken local varieties. The Valencian experience, where both Spanish and Catalan are official, helped me to realize the importance of bilinguism and its benefits; and now, that I'm living in Ecuador, South America, I'm understanding even more the richness that we have in Europe, with our great linguistical diversity. And I think that, nowadays, the protection of local cultures and minority languages is important like it has never been in human history; since we live in a standardizing era, I believe that the best way to appreciate other cultures is not to lose one‚Äôs culture, but to become aware of it and share it with the world. Indeed, in history, the progress has always come from communication and interaction between different cultures, and not from homologation. For this reason, my hope is that Lombard language, and all the other European minority and regional languages can gain social acceptance, and become official in the regions where they are spoken, like it happened with Catalan, Welsh, Sardinian, and many others.
fields.Video Description:
This video was recorded by Matteo Tignonsini in Ecuador. Lombard is spoken in the Lombardia region in Northern Italy, the South of Switzerland, and parts of eastern Piedmont and western Trentino. In this video Matteo shares with us that Lombard, like other regional languages, is often confused as an Italian dialect, even though UNESCO, ISO, and the broader linguistic community consider it its own language, and even though its closest relatives are French, Franco-Proven√ßal, Romansch, and Occitan. Since Lombard suffers from speaker loss particularly in Italy, the fact that it is not officially recognized in Italy is a matter of concern. Lombard does not hold direct lineage with Italian. The Ligures are thought to have left a mark on the Lombard language, but the record has preserved much more of the Celtish influence, rendering it a Gallo-Romance language. Lombard has several varieties within the provinces of Italy, and its oldest literary tradition exists in Milan, where the Milanese dialect has been overshadowed by Italian as Italian immigrants were drawn to the city by industrialization after the Second World War.

Lombard is spoken by almost four million people worldwide and is a Gallo-Romance language within the Italic branch of the Indo-European language family.
Demographics: 3,600,000 in Italy (2002). Population total all countries: 3,903,000.
